enrich_metadata.label: Swansboro, California
enrich_metadata.abstract: Swansboro Country; a subdivision within the community of Mosquito, is a residential area northeast of Placerville, the county seat of El Dorado County, California. The population was approximately 1,000 at the 2010 census. It is part of the Sacramento–Arden-Arcade–Roseville Metropolitan Statistical Area.

enrich_metadata.label: San Francisco
enrich_metadata.mention_address: SF, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: San Francisco (/sæn frənˈsɪskoʊ/), officially the City and County of San Francisco, is the cultural, commercial, and financial center of Northern California and the only consolidated city-county in California. San Francisco encompasses a land area of about 46.9 square miles (121 km2) on the northern end of the San Francisco Peninsula, which makes it the smallest county in the state. It has a density of about 18,187 people per square mile (7,022 people per km2), making it the most densely settled large city (population greater than 200,000) in the state of California and the second-most densely populated major city in the United States after New York City. San Francisco is the fourth-most populous city in California, after Los Angeles, San Diego and San Jose, and the 13th-most populous city in the United States—with a Census-estimated 2014 population of 852,469. The city and its surrounding areas are known as the San Francisco Bay Area, and are a part of the larger OMB designated San Jose-San Francisco-Oakland combined statistical area, the fifth most populous in the nation with an estimated population of 8.6 million. San Francisco (Spanish for Saint Francis) was founded on June 29, 1776, when colonists from Spain established Presidio of San Francisco at the Golden Gate and Mission San Francisco de Asís named for St. Francis of Assisi a few miles away. The California Gold Rush of 1849 brought rapid growth, making it the largest city on the West Coast at the time. San Francisco became a consolidated city-county in 1856.After three-quarters of the city was destroyed by the 1906 earthquake and fire, San Francisco was quickly rebuilt, hosting the Panama-Pacific International Exposition nine years later. In World War II, San Francisco was the port of embarkation for service members shipping out to the Pacific Theater. After the war, the confluence of returning servicemen, massive immigration, liberalizing attitudes, along with the rise of the "hippie" counterculture, the Sexual Revolution, the Peace Movement growing from opposition to United States involvement in the Vietnam War, and other factors led to the Summer of Love and the gay rights movement, cementing San Francisco as a center of liberal activism in the United States. Politically, the city votes strongly along liberal Democratic Party lines. San Francisco is a popular tourist destination, known for its cool summers, fog, steep rolling hills, eclectic mix of architecture, and landmarks including the Golden Gate Bridge, cable cars, the former Alcatraz Federal Penitentiary, Fisherman's Wharf, and its Chinatown district. San Francisco is also the headquarters of five major banking institutions and various other companies such as Levi Strauss & Co., Gap Inc., Salesforce.com, Dropbox, Reddit, Square, Inc., Dolby, Airbnb, Weebly, Pacific Gas and Electric Company, Yelp, Pinterest, Twitter, Uber, Mozilla, Wikimedia Foundation, and Craigslist. It has several nicknames, including "The City by the Bay", "Fog City", "San Fran", and "Frisco", as well as older ones like "The City that Knows How", "Baghdad by the Bay", and "The Paris of the West". As of 2015, San Francisco was ranked high on world livability rankings.

enrich_metadata.label: Oakland, California
enrich_metadata.mention_address: Oakland, Alameda County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: Oakland /ˈoʊklənd/ is a major West Coast port city in the U.S. state of California. Oakland is the third largest city in the San Francisco Bay Area, the eighth-largest city in California, and the 45th-largest city in the U.S. with a population of 413,775 as of 2014. It serves as a trade center for the San Francisco Bay Area; its Port of Oakland is the busiest port for San Francisco Bay, all of Northern California, and fifth busiest in the United States. Incorporated in 1852, Oakland is the county seat of Alameda County. It is also the principal city of the Bay Area Region known as the East Bay. The city is situated directly across the bay, six miles (9.7 km) east of San Francisco. Oakland's territory covers what was once a mosaic of coastal terrace prairie, oak woodland, and north coastal scrub. Its land served as a rich resource when its hillside oak and redwood timber were logged to build San Francisco, and Oakland's fertile flatland soils helped it become a prolific agricultural region. In the late 1860s, Oakland was selected as the western terminal of the Transcontinental Railroad. Following the 1906 San Francisco earthquake, many San Franciscans relocated to Oakland, enlarging the city's population, increasing its housing stock and improving its infrastructure. It continued to grow in the 20th century with its busy port, shipyards, and a thriving automobile manufacturing industry. Oakland is known for its sustainability practices, including a top ranking for usage of electricity from renewable resources. Oakland is also known for its history of political activism, as well as its professional sports franchises and major corporations, which include health care, dot-com companies and manufacturers of household products. In addition, thanks to a steady influx of immigrants during the 20th century, along with thousands of African-American war-industry workers who relocated from the Deep South during the 1940s, Oakland is one of the most ethnically diverse major cities in the country.

enrich_metadata.abstract: San Rafael (/ˌsæn rəˈfɛl/ SAN rə-FEL; [san rafaˈel]) (Spanish for "Saint Raphael") is a city and the county seat of Marin County, California, United States. The city is located in the North Bay region of the San Francisco Bay Area. As of the 2010 census the city's population is 57,713.

enrich_metadata.mention_address: San Carlos, San Mateo County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: San Carlos is a city in San Mateo County, California, USA on the San Francisco Peninsula, about halfway between San Francisco and San Jose. It is a small affluent residential suburb located between Belmont to the north and Redwood City to the south. The population was 28,406 at the 2010 census.

enrich_metadata.comment: San Carlos is a city in San Mateo County, California, USA on the San Francisco Peninsula, about halfway between San Francisco and San Jose. It is a small affluent residential suburb located between Belmont to the north and Redwood City to the south. The population was 28,406 at the 2010 census.

enrich_metadata.label: Richmond, California
enrich_metadata.mention_address: Richmond, Contra Costa County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: Richmond (/ˈrɪtʃmənd/ RICH-mənd) is a city in western Contra Costa County, California, United States. The city was incorporated on August 7, 1905. Located in the eastern region of the San Francisco Bay Area, Richmond borders the cities of San Pablo, Albany, El Cerrito and Pinole in addition to the unincorporated communities of North Richmond, Hasford Heights, Kensington, El Sobrante, Bayview-Montalvin Manor, Tara Hills, and East Richmond Heights, and briefly San Francisco on Red Rock Island. Under the McLaughlin Administration, Richmond was the largest city in the United States served by a Green Party mayor. As of the 2010 U.S. Census, the city's population is at 103,710, making it the second largest city in the United States to be named Richmond, after Richmond, Virginia.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Richmond,_California

attraction_reviewComments: We were here for a wedding and it served as a backdrop to the perfect spot. Awesome setting and big enough for many groups of beach goers too.
My husband and I were married here in June '12. Moonstone is such an incredible place that offers easy access to either side of the beach. Dog friendly. Make sure if you are... read more
We have been all up and down the west coast. Have visited the Trinidad area many times and somehow never walked Moonstone Beach. It is now our favorite west coast beach. Check... read more
the feel of the sand, the rock faces, good food nearby, great area to fly kites, good area for pictures
The road getting to this little beach is narrow and bumpy in places, so stay on the 101 until you have to get off. The beach itself is lovely: quiet, clearly a good place for dogs... read more
This time of year (March) the beach was pretty quiet and the dogs all well-behaved. An easy access beach to enjoy and relax.

enrich_metadata.label: San Diego
enrich_metadata.abstract: San Diego /ˌsæn diːˈeɪɡoʊ/ (Spanish for "Saint Didacus") is a major city in California, on the coast of the Pacific Ocean in Southern California, approximately 120 miles (190 km) south of Los Angeles and immediately adjacent to the border with Mexico. With an estimated population of 1,381,069 as of July 1, 2014, San Diego is the eighth-largest city in the United States and second-largest in California. San Diego is the birthplace of California and is known for its mild year-round climate, natural deep-water harbor, extensive beaches, long association with the U.S. Navy, and recent emergence as a healthcare and biotechnology development center. Historically home to the Kumeyaay people, San Diego was the first site visited by Europeans on what is now the West Coast of the United States. Upon landing in San Diego Bay in 1542, Juan Rodríguez Cabrillo claimed the entire area for Spain, forming the basis for the settlement of Alta California 200 years later. The Presidio and Mission of San Diego, founded in 1769, formed the first European settlement in what is now California. In 1821, San Diego became part of newly independent Mexico, and in 1850, became part of the United States following the Mexican–American War and the admission of California to the union. The city is the seat of San Diego County and is the economic center of the region as well as the San Diego–Tijuana metropolitan area. San Diego's main economic engines are military and defense-related activities, tourism, international trade, and manufacturing. The presence of the University of California, San Diego (UCSD), with the affiliated UCSD Medical Center, has helped make the area a center of research in biotechnology.

Had a ball! The kids (3 & 6 year old) loved all the rides. I loved the cotton candy and the view!

Went to the pier to take a look around, all sorts of interesting "characters" there. Lots of activity and people milling about, vendors of every variety hawking their... read more

We had such a beautiful day in Santa Monica, the pier just beckoned to us, so it was our first stop. There are lots of vendors,street performers and restaurants along the pier... read more
A lovely Pier to walk to and if lucky to go on the rides if they are open.There was a man singing at the end of the Pier he was really good we sat and listened and watched the... read more

From the welcome sign on Colorado to the end, the pier is full of sights, sounds, and yes, smells (mostly food).
Enjoy the view,play games eat snacks,watch the trapeze school or participate.Goon the Ferris wheel and the ride bicycles on the bike path along the beach to Venice!
We enjoyed walking down the pier. My son rode a couple of the rides. The view is beautiful, especially at sunset.
A 20 minute walk. A gaming arcade and some fairground rides to go on. Basic really.

enrich_metadata.label: Civic Center, Bakersfield
enrich_metadata.mention_address: Bakersfield, Kern County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: Civic Center is a district in Downtown Bakersfield, California. It is the center of government for the City of Bakersfield and the County of Kern, containing a collection of buildings used by the city, county, state, and federal governments. The district also contains all of downtown's sporting complexes. It also has the Rabobank Theater and Convention Center, which is the largest theater and convention facilities in the city.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Civic_Center,_Bakersfield
enrich_metadata.comment: Civic Center is a district in Downtown Bakersfield, California. enrich_metadata.label: Palmdale, California
enrich_metadata.mention_address: Palmdale, Los Angeles County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: Palmdale is a city in the center of northern Los Angeles County in the U.S. state of California. The San Gabriel Mountains separate Palmdale from the City of Los Angeles. On August 24, 1962, Palmdale became the first community in the Antelope Valley to incorporate. 47 years later, in November 2009, voters approved making it a charter city. Its population was 152,750 at the 2010 census, up from 116,670 at the 2000 census. Palmdale is the 33rd most populous city in California. In 2013, the Palmdale / Lancaster urban area had an estimated population of 513,547.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Palmdale,_California
enrich_metadata.comment: Palmdale is a city in the center of northern Los Angeles County in the U.S. state of California. The San Gabriel Mountains separate Palmdale from the City of Los Angeles.On August 24, 1962, Palmdale became the first community in the Antelope Valley to incorporate. 47 years later, in November 2009, voters approved making it a charter city. Its population was 152,750 at the 2010 census, up from 116,670 at the 2000 census. Palmdale is the 33rd most populous city in California. In 2013, the Palmdale / Lancaster urban area had an estimated population of 513,547.

enrich_metadata.label: Inglewood, California
enrich_metadata.mention_address: Inglewood, Los Angeles County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: Inglewood is a city in southwestern Los Angeles County, California, southwest of downtown Los Angeles. As of the 2010 U.S. Census, the city had a population of 109,673. It was incorporated on February 14, 1908. The city is in the South Bay region of the Greater Los Angeles Area. City of Champions Stadium is under construction in the city and when finished around 2019 will be the home of the Los Angeles Rams, which moved back to the Los Angeles Area in 2016.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Inglewood,_California
enrich_metadata.comment: Inglewood is a city in southwestern Los Angeles County, California, southwest of downtown Los Angeles. As of the 2010 U.S. Census, the city had a population of 109,673. It was incorporated on February 14, 1908. The city is in the South Bay region of the Greater Los Angeles Area. City of Champions Stadium is under construction in the city and when finished around 2019 will be the home of the Los Angeles Rams, which moved back to the Los Angeles Area in 2016.

enrich_metadata.label: Ukiah, California
enrich_metadata.abstract: Ukiah (/juːˈkaɪ.ə/ yew-KY-ə; formerly Ukiah City) is the county seat and largest city of Mendocino County, California. With its accessible location (along the U.S. Route 101 corridor several miles south of CA 20), Ukiah serves as the city center for Mendocino County and much of neighboring Lake County. The Ukiah Valley is a center of a major wine production industry. In 1996, Ukiah was ranked the #1 best small town to live in California and the sixth-best place to live in the United States. The population was 16,075 at the 2010 census.

enrich_metadata.label: Dana Point, California
enrich_metadata.abstract: Dana Point is a city located in southern Orange County, California. The population was 33,351 at the 2010 census. It has one of the few harbors along the Orange County coast, and with ready access via State Route 1, it is a popular local destination for surfing. The city was named after the headland of Dana Point, which was in turn named after Richard Henry Dana, Jr., author of Two Years Before the Mast, which included a description of the area. Dana described the locale, including neighboring San Juan Capistrano, as "the only romantic spot on the coast". Although Dana described the anchorage as poor, it is now a developed harbor and contains a replica of his ship, the Pilgrim. The Pilgrim is used as a classroom by the Ocean Institute, which is located at the harbor. This area is designated California Historical Landmark #189.

enrich_metadata.label: Beverly Hills, California
enrich_metadata.abstract: Beverly Hills is a city in Los Angeles County, California, United States, surrounded by the cities of Los Angeles and West Hollywood. Originally a Spanish ranch where lima beans were grown, Beverly Hills was incorporated in 1914 by a group of investors who had failed to find oil, but found water instead and eventually decided to develop it into a town. By 2013, its population had grown to 34,658. Sometimes referred to as "90210", one of its primary ZIP codes, it is home to many actors and celebrities. The city includes the Rodeo Drive shopping district and the Beverly Hills Oil Field.

enrich_metadata.label: Lakewood, California
enrich_metadata.mention_address: Lakewood, Los Angeles County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: Lakewood is a city in Los Angeles County, California, United States. The population was 80,048 at the 2010 census. It is bordered by Long Beach on the west and south, Bellflower on the north, Cerritos on the northeast, Cypress on the east, and Hawaiian Gardens on the southeast. Major thoroughfares include Lakewood (SR 19), Bellflower, and Del Amo Boulevards and Carson and South Streets. The San Gabriel River Freeway (I-605) runs through the city's eastern regions. Sometimes called "an instant city" because of its origins—going from lima bean fields in 1950 to a well-developed city by 1960—Lakewood is a classic example of a post–World War II American suburb.

It is bordered by Long Beach on the west and south, Bellflower on the north, Cerritos on the northeast, Cypress on the east, and Hawaiian Gardens on the southeast. Major thoroughfares include Lakewood (SR 19), Bellflower, and Del Amo Boulevards and Carson and South Streets. The San Gabriel River Freeway (I-605) runs through the city's eastern regions.

attraction_reviewComments: We went with my son's class in the evening. We went straight to the tidepools so didn't see much else, but the tidepools we excellent.
MacKerricher is a sprawling state park with uncrowded beaches, hiking trails, and rugged coastline views. It's just three miles north of Fort Bragg along the rugged Mendocino... read more
After a long day of navigating US101 and CA1, it was great to sit on the rocks and watch and listen to the ocean roar in. It was foggy, but still so beautiful.
This is truly a beautiful park. It has so much-the beach, beautiful views, a boardwalk, tidal pools, and watching the seals and sea lions. I was surprised there isn't a day use... read more
Always love staying here because of the proximity to the beach. They could use an update to their bathrooms-several of the showers were broken the week we stayed here.
They´ve built a nice clean and level wooden walkway to the area overlooking the crashing waves - great for those on wheels or with more challenged mobility.
This place is breath taking. I love the walk around the whole park.
We camped here in our small pop-up trailer for 6 nights with our 8yo daughter. Our campsite was fabulous - large, flat parking area, lots of trees surrounding it, loved it. Some... read more
As stated in my title this is an extraordinary bike, running, pet walking & walking trail. I can't tell you all of the different sights to see along this beautiful trail which... read more
Went for a day visit. came here to get out of summer heat. Unlike most state parks, dogs can go on most trails. Nice ocean view and trail along beach. Trail around lake nice easy... read more
We didn't have reservations (mistake), but a wonderful gal (wish I'd gotten her name so I could send a letter to the park hq) at the front gate found a campsite for us. The place... read more
We've camped here for almost 4 decades. Great for kids. You can walk to the beach, or drive 4 miles into Ft Bragg. We don't need hookups, and some large rigs won't fit. Reserve... read more
Great walk boardwalk got to see seals and friendly squirrels Wheelchair accessible and toilets close to town and plenty of parking
I love the hadicapped boardwalk on the headlands. I'm a bird watcher and the trail offers a good variety. I added a Black Oyster Catcher to my life list on the beach.
We visited MacKerricher and we were not disappointed. We saw seals on the beach and a deer in the park who eating lunch. He kept watching us so we did not frighten him.
Go visit the tide pools at low tide to see all the little sea animals! Be careful not to slip though..
We love coming here and have camped here in the past. We only wish the trail around Cleone Lake were maintained. Wheelchair accessible boardwalk to the ocean views is also great... read more
We love the walking trails and of course the beach. Lots of people go to this beach with dogs, which should always be welcome.
I recommend going at low tide. The park is easily accessible by boardwalk with an area of beach containing many tidal pools with crabs and sea anemones. The views are stunning and... read more
Easy parking, lots of trails. Includes elevated boardwalk type trails with benches, points of interest displays. Have never camped here but sites seem to be secluded and private... read more
MacKerricher State Park is always on our list of "must do's" when we visit the Fort Bragg area. The tidal pools are the best. Be sure to check for the low tide schedule and try... read more
Lots of great camping spots. There are trails for biking and walking within the park and along the coastal area. Beautiful views of the ocean and coastline.
A beautiful state park with easy access to tide pools and look outs. It was handicapped accessible. One could easily spend a lot of time exploring the area.
Take a walk to the tidal pools. Walk around the lake. Make a picnic out of it. Life is so laid back and slow here.
Pretty park, very clean and wonderful sunsets.Free for a daily visit and they also have camping.beach was really nice
Arrived just before sunset and were given directions to the perfect viewing spot nearby. The park rangers were very helpful. Restrooms were nice and the showers were wonderful... read more
I prefer MacKerricher because I like the heavy wooded feel and not being able to see my neighboring campers. Everything is kept clean and maintained. They had nice beach access... read more
Nice easy boardwalk trail to the cliffs. Can whale watch and also view seals. Tide pool is accesible for kids to explore.
We walked out on the board walk and the view was just beautiful. A woman was bird watching and let us look through her telescope. Such a pretty area.
We love MacKerricher! When our children were little, we ca,e here to camp. Now we sleep in real beds, but still visit the park. Day Use is free and allows visitors to stay until... read more
It is just a spectacular place with grand views of the bay and ocean. The only downside is the walkway for Cleone Lake was closed for repairs and there is currently no budget to... read more
Nice boardwalk to walk around the park and beach area to view the seals. It was a little nippy that day but we enjoyed the boardwalk and were entertained by people feeding... read more
Definitely visit this park. Almost every picture we took looks like a post card. The views are incredible. There's wildlife at the end of the walk ways, definitely bring a camera.
We visited the park after booking 3 nights at a private hidden pines campground which turned out to be a nightmare. MacKerricher State Park is beautiful & clean with spectacular... read more
For my first introduction to camping, this was a great place to choose. The ranger greeted me with a map, explained the process, and made suggestions. I think it was $20 for an... read more
wonderful ocean views, lots of marine life to see. A wonderful boardwalk. It was a beautiful evening to be in Ft. Bragg and vicinity.
Go visit. Great spot in Fort Bragg! Went to watch the sunset, was very very impressed. Great walking/hiking trails, and tide pools.
This park is very accessible and the ocean overlooks allow for great views of the seals. It's easy to get out and do a little ocean rock climbing to find some tide pools and... read more
Stayed for a weekend camping trip. The weather was perfect which helped! Campground was beautiful, clean and well maintained. Rangers were extremely friendly and helpful. Large... read more
I loved everything about it,the tide pools were great and very excessable,would love to camp here sometime
Nice walkway with easy handicapped access. Beautiful ocean side stroll. Several places to access beach.
There was no fee for day use. There are fees for overnight camping as expected. Great trails for walking or even to ride your bike. The park is well maintained as most state parks... read more
This was a gorgeous park, definitely worth a visit. The boardwalk provides some really nice places to look. Lots of seals and sea lions, and lots of birds. Lovely!
Great place to walk or bike. We went a bit north of there as well for a wonderful, long bike ride on a trail.
This park is super clean and gorgeous! Great tidepools and a boardwalk path that is wheelchair accessible. A platform for whale watching during their migration too. We took the... read more
Love the walk out to the point. Lots of animals to observe and some history about the area on the walk out. The bathrooms needed some cleaning.

We came to walk the board walk it was quite nice and relaxing. The tidal pools were interesting even though we didn't see many creatures. Saw a gull grab a very large crab out of... read more
didn't expect to spend much time in fort bragg but we ended up really liking the area. the park is excellent and we will probably reserve camping in the future and plan an... read more
My kids loved this place. The scenery, with the coastal mountains, and crashing waves, will take your breath away. And then you look down and a furry little critter is begging... read more
go to the loop with 125 to 143. Sites from 135 to 143 are great for a more private space. Other ones are good for more open space and larger groups. The park has tons of walking... read more
We walk MacKerricher each year we visit the Mendocino area. It has been beautiful every time. We've seen whales, fields of Goldfields flowers & pelicans. We like every trail for... read more
We just love coming here. Very family friendly campground. Hard to find a bad campsite. We just stayed in 70 and 72. 72 was awesome and large. Bathrooms are well maintained. Close... read more
Well, folks it's changed a bit. The area near the lake flooded some years ago, but it's almost back to normal. Famous for it's black sand beach ,tide pools, seal point look-out... read more
My husband & I have been gooing to MacKerricher for at least 37 yrs.and and all so are children when they were young and now we take are dogs over to fort bragg we will stay a few... read more
We stay here with a large group every year, but definitely have to plan 6 mos in advance. Family friendly with the beach and bike trails handy.

enrich_metadata.label: Arcata, California
enrich_metadata.abstract: Arcata, California Arcata (Hupa: do'-khah-oon-tetl ding', meaning "big flat place") originally Union Town or Union, is a city adjacent to the Arcata Bay (northern) portion of Humboldt Bay in Humboldt County, California, United States. At the 2010 census, Arcata's population was 17,231. Arcata, located 280 miles (450 km) north of San Francisco (via Highway 101), is home to Humboldt State University. Arcata is also the location of the Arcata Field Office of the Federal Bureau of Land Management, which is responsible for the administration of natural resources, lands, and mineral programs, including the Headwaters Forest, on approximately 200,000 acres of public land in Northwestern California.

enrich_metadata.label: Burbank, California
enrich_metadata.mention_address: Burbank, Los Angeles County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: Burbank is a city in Los Angeles County in Southern California, United States, 12 miles (19 km) northwest of downtown Los Angeles. The population at the 2010 census was 103,340. Billed as the "Media Capital of the World" and only a few miles northeast of Hollywood, numerous media and entertainment companies are headquartered or have significant production facilities in Burbank, including The Walt Disney Company, Warner Bros. Entertainment, ABC Studios, ABC Family, Marvel Studios, Nickelodeon, NBC, and Insomniac Games. The city is also home to Bob Hope Airport. Burbank also holds a special place in aerospace history since Lockheed's Skunk Works in Burbank produced some of the most secret and technologically advanced airplanes, including the U-2 spy planes that uncovered the Soviet Union missile components in Cuba. Burbank consists of two distinct areas: a downtown, in the foothills of the Verdugo Mountains, and flatlands, at the east end of the San Fernando Valley. At one time, it was referred to as "Beautiful Downtown Burbank" on Laugh-In and The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson. The city was named after David Burbank, a New Hampshire-born dentist and entrepreneur.

enrich_metadata.label: Berkeley, California
enrich_metadata.mention_address: Berkeley, Alameda County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: Berkeley (/ˈbɜːrkliː/ BURK-lee) is a city on the east shore of San Francisco Bay in northern Alameda County, California. It is named after the 18th-century Anglo-Irish bishop and philosopher George Berkeley. It borders the cities of Oakland and Emeryville to the south and the city of Albany and unincorporated community of Kensington to the north. Its eastern border with Contra Costa County generally follows the ridge of the Berkeley Hills. Its population at the 2010 census was 112,580. Berkeley is the site of the oldest campus in the University of California system – the University of California, Berkeley – of the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory which is managed and operated by the university, and the Graduate Theological Union. It is one of the most politically liberal cities in the United States.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Berkeley,_California
enrich_metadata.comment: Berkeley (/ˈbɜːrkliː/ BURK-lee) is a city on the east shore of San Francisco Bay in northern Alameda County, California. It is named after the 18th-century Anglo-Irish bishop and philosopher George Berkeley. It borders the cities of Oakland and Emeryville to the south and the city of Albany and unincorporated community of Kensington to the north. Its eastern border with Contra Costa County generally follows the ridge of the Berkeley Hills. Its population at the 2010 census was 112,580.
